text:
Hi all! I'm looking for some input on how to best handle the issue of module IDs when working in local development with GitHub actions and contentstaging/sandboxes.
The issue I'm having is the following
I'm trying to create a staging environment for our websites using github actions to push to two different themes, one called Web and one called Web Staging. I'll be working on the staging theme and through a github action, I'll push the content into the Web theme once it's ready.
My issue however is {% module "module_48309189302" path="..." %}, i was hoping i could just use an environment variable in the path to distinguish between Web and Web Staging but it seems I'm required to include the module ID. These aren't the same - so what do I do?
<@UTRKEGMKQ> Canâ€™t you just give it a name and use that as identifier?
Good question! I'll try it right away
That is not the module ID, but the module instance id, so call it however you want ("hero_module", "module_1", etc)

So {% module "Hero" path="/Web/modules/Dynamic modules/car_models/Hero", label="Hero"%} would be the same as

{% module "module_17187928272084" path="/Web/modules/Dynamic modules/car_models/Hero", label="Hero"%}`?
Youre right! Thank you both so much! :heart: I really got my head stuck in the gutter

TIP: i suggest to always call the id in lowercase and separated by an underscore, otherwise I noticed that if you use "export_to_template_context" and try to reference the module instance it won't work
Is there any benefit to calling it something instead of just keeping with the auto generated module_number?
no, I just prefer to give em an human readable id so that the code is more clean
